children.name: to make liquid or a substance come out
pour
children.definition: to make liquid or a substance flow steadily out of a container, by making the container lean to one side: rót, đổ, giội, trút
examples: She poured coffee for everyone.

children.name: pour in/out
examples: Gradually pour in the sherry and the stock.

children.name: pour sth into/out/down etc (sth)
examples: Pour the oil into a frying pan and heat.

children.name: pour sth on/over/into sth
examples: Pour the garlic sauce over the hot chicken pieces.

children.name: pour sb sth
examples: Why don’t youpouryourself anotherdrink?

children.name: pour sth away(= get rid of something )
examples: The wine was so bad I just poured it away.

children.name: spill
children.definition: if you spill a liquid, or if it spills, it accidentally flows over the edge of a container : làm tràn, tràn ra
examples: Katie almost spilled her milk.
Careful - you’ll spill it!

children.name: spill sth down/on/over sth
examples: Oh no! I’ve spilt coffee all down my shirt!

children.name: spill on/over etc
examples: He slipped and the wine spilled all over the carpet.

children.name: empty
children.definition: to make a container empty by pouring out everything inside it: đổ, trút, làm cạn
examples: Paul emptied the glass and washed it.
Could you empty the wastebasket - it’s getting pretty full.
Did you empty the dishwasher?

children.name: empty sth into/onto/over sth
examples: She emptied the contents of the tin into a pan.
We crept up behind him and emptied the bucket of water over his head.
Elinor emptied the contents of the envelope onto the table.
He emptied out the ashtray.

children.name: sprinkle
children.definition: to pour or put a liquid or substance in small amounts onto sth, especially food, so that the surface is thinly covered : tưới, rải, rắc

children.name: sprinkle sth on/over sth
examples: Sprinkle the cheese over the beans.
I sprinkled cocoa over my latte.

children.name: sprinkle sth with sth
examples: Sprinkle the fish with lemon juice and herbs.
Sprinkle the top with cheese.

children.name: tip
children.definition: to pour something from one place or container into another : đổ sang

children.name: tip sth onto/into sth
examples: Tip the onions and oil into a large ovenproof dish.
Ben tipped the contents of the drawer onto the table.
He tipped the cup of milk into the pan.
She weighed out the flour and tipped it into the bowl.

children.name: tip sth out
examples: Shall I tip the water out?

children.name: drizzle
children.definition: to pour a liquid in small amounts over something, especially food - used especially in cooking instructions: “mưa phùn”
examples: drizzle[S] a small amount of liquid that is lightly poured over something
Serve the pasta hot with a drizzle of olive oil.

children.name: drizzle something over something
examples: Drizzle a little French dressing over the salad.

children.name: drizzle something with something
examples: Slice the strawberries and drizzle them with the liqueur.

children.name: spray
children.definition: to force liquid out of a container so that it comes out in a stream of very small drops and covers an area →squirt: xịt

children.name: spray somebody/something with something
examples: She sprayed herself with perfume.

children.name: spray something on/onto/over something
examples: Someone had sprayed blue paint over his car.
Vandals had sprayed graffiti on the walls.

children.name: spray crops/plants etc(= cover them with liquid to protect them from insects or disease )
examples: The fruit is sprayed every four weeks.

children.name: decant
children.definition: to pour liquid from one container into another container – a rather formal use : gạn

children.name: decant sth into sth
examples: Rachel decanted the shampoo into small bottles for travelling.
He often decanted cheap whisky into bottles of more expensive brands.

children.name: when liquid, gas, etc moves in a stream
flow
children.definition: when a liquid, gas, flows, it moves in a steady continuous stream
examples: The river flows more slowly here and it is safe to swim.

children.name: flow over/down/through etc
examples: These gates regulate the amount of water flowing into the canal.
If the windows are shut, air cannotflow freelythrough the building.
Tears flowed down her cheeks as she hugged her children.
Oil flowed from the tanker into the sea.

children.name: flow into/out of
examples: From here, factory waste flows straight into the sea.

children.name: run
children.definition: 1 if a liquid s somewhere, it flows quickly and smoothly– used when saying that something flows in a particular direction
examples: 2[ intransitive and transitive ] if a tap is running, water is coming out of it, or if you run a tap, you make water come out of it :
Did you leave the tap running?
He ran the tap until the water was really hot.
Who left the faucet running?

children.name: run along/down etc
examples: Water was running off the roof.
Tears started to run down her cheeks.
Tears ran down her face.
A stream runs along the bottom of the field.

children.name: trickle
children.definition: if liquid trickles somewhere, it flows slowly and without force in a thin line: chảy thành dòng
examples: trickle[S] dòng chảy nhỏ giọt
The raging torrent had been reduced to no more than a trickle.
A trickle of melted butter made its way down his chin.

children.name: trickle down/into/out
examples: The tears trickled down her cheeks.
Blood trickled down the side of her face.
Water trickled out of the pipe.
The fire spread when burning gasoline trickled from the car toward other vehicles.

children.name: when liquid flows over the edges of a container
overflow
children.definition: if a liquid overflows or if a river, lake, or container overflows, it is so full that the liquid or material inside flows over its edges : tràn
examples: The drains flooded and water overflowed down the main street.
The river had overflowed its banks.
The milk overflowed when I poured it into the jug.
Because of heavy rain, the river may overflow its banks.
Oh no, the bath is overflowing all over the floor.
overflow with
waste bins overflowing with plastic cups

children.name: flow
children.definition: a smooth steady movement of liquid, gas

children.name: flow of
examples: He struggled to swim against the flow of the water.
I tied a towel round his leg to try tostemtheflowof blood.

children.name: drip
children.definition: 1 to let liquid fall in drops :
examples: Thetap’s dripping.
Her boots were muddy and herhair was dripping.
drip blood/water/sweat etc
John came in, his arm dripping blood.
be dripping with blood/sweat etc
The hand that held the gun was dripping with sweat.
2[I] if a liquid drips, it falls slowly and steadily, in drops: chảy nhỏ giọt , chảy từng giọt, rơi từng hạt
drip down/from etc
Therain drippeddown his neck.
Waterwasdrippingthrough the ceiling.
The blood was still dripping from the cut on his lip.
We stood under a tree, with rain dripping onto our heads.
Wax from the candle dripped on the tablecloth.
drip[ C ] a drop of liquidgiọt
drips of paint/sweat

children.name: trickle
children.definition: if liquid trickles somewhere, it flows slowly in drops or in a thin stream : chảy nhỏ giọt
examples: trickle down/from/out of, etc.
The tears trickled down her cheeks.
Blood trickled down the side of her face.
Water trickled out of the pipe.
The fire spread when burning gasoline trickled from the car toward other vehicles.

children.name: cascade
children.definition: to flow, fall, or hang down in large quantities :
examples: cascade from/into/down etc
Gallons of water cascaded over the side of the bath.
Water cascades down the hilllside.
The walls of the cave are smooth, polished by the water cascading from above.
Water from the broken water main cascaded into a subway station.
cascade[C]
cascade of
Rainbows glanced off the cascade of the waterfall.

children.name: when liquid, gas, etc comes out
leak
children.definition: 1 if a container, pipe, roof etc s, or if it leaks gas, liquid etc, there is a small hole or crack in it that lets gas or liquid flow through :
examples: I think the fuel tank is leaking.
A tanker is leaking oil off the coast of Scotland.
leak through/into/out of/from
Yoghurt had leaked out of the pot all over my lunchbox.
2[I always + adverb/preposition ] if a gas or liquid leaks somewhere, it gets through a hole in somethingSYN seep
leak through/into/out of/from
Water was leaking from a pipe in the bathroom.
Sea water was leaking into the batteries which powered the electric motors.
leak[C] B2
1a small hole that lets liquid or gas flow into or out of something :
There is a leak in the ceiling.
There's water on the floor - we must have a leak.
2 a gas/oil/water etc leakan escape of gas or liquid through a hole in something :
A gas leak caused the explosion.
If you suspect agasleak, phone the emergency number.

children.name: The boat hadsprung a leak
children.definition: a hole had appeared in it

children.name: pour
children.definition: if a lot of liquid or smoke pours out, it comes out from somewhere in very large amounts : phun ra, trào ra

children.name: pour out of/off/down etc
examples: Smoke was pouring out of the upstairs windows.
Blood was pouring from his nose.
Sweat poured down his face.
Water was pouring out of the release gates on the dam.
Rain poured through the open window, waking me again an hour later.
Lava from the volcano is pouring down the mountain towards the town.

children.name: come out U
children.definition: come out if liquid comes out of a pipe, container etc, it flows out fairly slowly and in fairly small quantities: chảy ra
examples: When I turned on the tap a brownish liquid came out.

children.name: come out of
examples: There’s oil coming out of your engine.
I can’t get the ketchup to come out of the bottle.

children.name: gush
children.definition: a) if a liquid es, it flows or pours out quickly and in large quantitiesSYN spurt: phun trào, chảy ào ào
examples: gush out/from/down etc
Water gushed from the broken pipe.
He opened the door and smoke gushed out.
Oil gushed from the hole in the ship’s hull.
A pipe burst in one of the apartments above, and water gushed down.
b)[T] if sth gushes a liquid, the liquid pours out quickly and in large quantitiesSYN spurt:
The wound gushed blood.
The knife wound was gushing blood.
gush[S]
gush of
A sudden gush of liquid spurted out of the plant

children.name: ooze
children.definition: if a thick liquid oozes from something or if something oozes a thick liquid, that liquid flows from it very slowly

children.name: ooze from/out of/through
examples: The ice cream was melting and oozing out of its wrapper.
A cut on his cheek was still oozing blood.
A mixture of mud and rainwater oozed out of the bottom of the bucket.
Blood was oozing from the wound.
Thick, sticky syrup oozes out of the tree trunk and is collected in buckets.

children.name: spurt
children.definition: a) if liquid or flames  from something, they come out of it quickly and suddenly : phun ra/ vọt ra
examples: spurt from/out of/into
Blood spurted from his nose.
Oil from the spill spurted into the crystal waters of Prince William Sound. Dầu từ sự cố tràn dầu bắn vào
Water spurted from the burst pipe. Nước phun trào từ ống nước vỡ
b)[T] to send out liquid quickly or suddenly :
It boiled over, spurting hot water everywhere.
spurt[C]
The whale sent one final spurt into the air and disappeared
The water came outinspurts.

children.name: squirt
children.definition: 1 if you  liquid or it squirts, it is forced out of a narrow hole in a thin fast stream: phun, bắn, phịt
examples: squirt out/from/into
Water suddenly squirted out from a hole in the pipe.
squirt sth on sb/sth
He squirted some ketchup on his fries.
squirt sth into/through sth
Squirt some oil in the lock.
2[T] to hit or cover sb/sth with a thin fast stream of liquid →spray
Kids were squirting each other with water pistols.
squirt sb/sth with sth
Mom! Chad’s squirting me with the hose!
Some kids squirted a water pistol in her face.
squirt[C]
squirt of
Add a couple of squirts of lemon juice to the mixture.

children.name: splash
children.definition: 1 if a liquid es, it hits or falls on something and makes a noise : bắn tung tóe
examples: splash against/on/over
The ocean splashed against the pier.
2[T always + adverb/preposition ] to make someone or something wet with a lot of small drops of water or other liquid : vẩy, té
splash something on/over/with etc something
He splashed cold water on his face.
3[I] (alsosplash about/around) to make water fly up in the air with a loud noise by hitting it or by moving around in it :
The children were splashing about in the pool.
splash through
She ran up the drive, splashing through the puddles.
splash[C] C2 a small amount of a liquid which has fallen or been dropped
There were several splashes of white paint on the carpet.

children.name: flow
children.definition: the continuous stream of words or ideas when someone is speaking, writing, or thinking about something :
examples: I didn’t want tointerruptherflow, so I said nothing.

children.name: run
children.definition: verbrunning,ran,runFLOW

children.name: flow
children.definition: the movement of goods, people, or information from one place to another
examples: flow of
the flow of funds from the US to Europe
There has been asteady flowof people leaving the area.
They have accused the government of trying to block thefree flowof information.
an attempt tostemtheflowof refugees across the border
